PULAU TEKONG BESAR AND PULAU UBIN
(Electricity supply)

ASEAN SCHOLARSHIP STUDENTS
STUDYING IN SINGAPORE
(Particulars)


    2. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Prime Minister (a) whether he has figures for 1976, 1977 and 1978 of students from ASEAN countries, who have been granted state scholarships to study in our two universities; (b) whether the offer of such state scholarships will affect the opportunities of our own students for the same scholarships; and (c) whether he is aware of any criticism from our ASEAN neighbours that the offer of our state scholarships is causing a brain-drain in their countries.

Column: 286



     The Minister for Law and Science and Technology (Mr E.W. Barker) (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Prime Minister has asked me to reply on his behalf.

    The number of undergraduate scholarships awarded to students from ASEAN countries to study at our local universities was 21 in 1976, 21 in 1977 and 43 in 1978. In the same years, 121, 105 and 251 scholarships respectively were awarded to Singapore citizens. This is about five or six times more than those awarded to foreign students. In addition, about 100 scholarships were awarded to Singapore citizens to study overseas every year.

    The number of ASEAN scholarships awarded does not affect the number of scholarships for Singaporeans. We can afford to give as many scholarships as there are deserving Singaporeans. In any case, many of these ASEAN scholarships are for teaching; scholarships which are not keenly sought after by Singaporeans.

    The numbers of scholarships awarded are insignificant to the places we provide for private students from ASEAN countries for further studies here. We cannot assume that these students will not return home after their studies.

     Mr Ho See Beng (Khe Bong): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister concerned whether he will consider withdrawing the scholarships if our Government is aware that the offer of these scholarships to ASEAN students is causing a brain-drain in their countries.

     Mr Barker: Sir, we will cross the bridge when we come to the river. At the moment, there is no brain-drain. As I stated just now, the Member is assuming that these ASEAN students will not go home, whether they are scholars or private students. So far they have all gone home. So there is no question of withdrawing the scholarships. Their numbers are small. These countries are friendly to us, and I think it is a good thing if we carry on giving them scholarships.

TRANSFER OF TEACHERS TO THE NINE SELECTED
CHINESE SECONDARY SCHOOLS


    3. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Education (a) how many teachers from how many schools have been transferred to the nine selected Chinese secondary schools; (b) whether the move has created problems for the schools from which those teachers have been transferred; and (c) how replacement will be made.

     The Senior Minister of State for Education (Mr Chai Chong Yii) (for the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, a total of 42 teachers from 32 schools were transferred to the nine selected Chinese secondary schools. The vacancies arising in the 32 schools were filled mainly by cadet teachers. The withdrawal of even a single teacher from any school must cause some disruption. However, a breakdown shows that of the 32 schools, one released three teachers, eight released two teachers and the remaining 23 released one teacher each. The release of more than one teacher by a school was conditioned by such factors as distance, the specific needs of schools and the standing of the teachers.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Sir, would the 42 teachers from the 32 schools transferred to the nine selected Chinese secondary schools be sufficient to meet the requirements of teaching? Also, Sir, would the hon. Senior Minister of State give us the breakdown figures of the medium of teaching of these teachers?

     Mr Chai Chong Yii: Sir, in addition to the 42 teachers transferred from other schools, another 32 were posted to the nine schools to meet curriculum needs. Of these 32, 23 were Institute of Education graduands and 3 cadet teachers, six were inter-transfer among the nine schools because of curriculum adjustment. Of the total of 74 teachers posted, 67 were of the English medium and seven were of the Chinese medium.

APPOINTMENT OF SCHOOL VICE-PRINCIPALS
(Numbers and effect)


    4. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Education (a) how many senior teachers have been appointed vice-principals; whether he is aware that some of them are unhappy over the so-called promotion, and if he will respect their wish to continue teaching in the schools without penalty; and (b) whether he is aware that, as a result of such exercise, a number of schools have as at 15th January, 1979, been unable to draw up proper time-tables resulting in pupils having nothing to do during certain periods in the schools concerned, and what steps he will take to ensure that no more precious time is lost to the school curricula.

     Mr Chai Chong Yii (for the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Education): Sir, as at 18th January, 1979, a total of 122 officers were offered appointment as Vice-Principals. Of this number, 15 declined appointment and were not only released immediately but were posted back to their original schools. No officer will be compelled to accept appointment or suffer any penalty if he or she indicates a preference to continue teaching. However, it is incumbent on the Ministry to initially offer appointment to all eligible officers. The initial appointment of 122 Vice-Principals could not have had the effect of so disrupting schools that, as late as 15th January, 1979, they were not able to draw up time-tables. Of the 122, 22 remained in their same schools, 13 schools had two officers posted out as Vice-Principals, two schools had three officers posted out as Vice-Principals, one school had five, four were HQ officers and the remaining 52 schools each had one officer posted out. Seven of the officers who declined appointment have yet to be replaced.

    Although a few schools faced problems in time-tabling at the beginning of this year, these problems were due to factors such as posting of pupils and choice of schools for immersion classes. The problems of time-tabling have since been resolved.

FULL-DAY SCHOOLS
(Implementation)


    5. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Education what are the schools in which full-day schooling will be introduced, and how will the curriculum for those schools be worked out.

     Mr Chai Chong Yii (for the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, in the Addendum to the Presidential Address for the financial years 1979 to 1982, the Ministry of Education has indicated that a pilot project on full-day schooling for secondary schools will be introduced in 1980.

    The objectives of this project are to allow a more thorough treatment of the curriculum and to provide better interaction between pupils and teachers. Salient features of the full-day school programme will be the provision of a wider choice of elective subjects; time for remedial teaching, small group tutorials, private studies with close supervision by teachers; and the provision of guidance and counselling to help pupils who have difficulties in their work. Pupils in full-day schools should be able to do all the work they may be given during the school day itself.

    Prerequisites for the successful implementation of the project include the commitment of principals and teachers to its objectives; the cooperation of teachers' unions; and the careful selection of schools that should be adequately equipped with all the necessary facilities required for a full-day school. Schools which are to pioneer this scheme should be preferably located in HDB estates so that teachers and pupils involved in the project need not travel far from their homes.

    The Ministry of Education is in the process of finalising the implementation details of this project.

BOARD OF TERTIARY EDUCATION


    6. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Education

Column: 290

whether it is considered necessary to set up a Board of Tertiary Education to be solely in charge of the two universities, the Institute of Education, the Singapore Polytechnic and the Ngee Ann Technical College so that the curricular planning, academic development, use of facilities, staffing and the allocation and distribution of students in the five institutes can be better co-ordinated and complemented in order to prevent wastage and unnecessary duplication or overlapping.

     The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Education (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Sir, the Ministry does not consider it necessary to set up a Board of Tertiary Education to be solely in charge of the two Universities, the Institute of Education, the Singapore Polytechnic and the Ngee Ann Technical College. This step is not only unnecessary but it is not likely to achieve the objectives that the hon. Member has in mind.

    So far as admission of students is concerned, there has been established since 1978 a joint admission board which considers applications from students who passed their 'O' level for entry into Junior Colleges, Pre-U Centres, Singapore Polytechnic, Ngee Ann Technical College and the Industrial Training Board. Admissions into the University of Singapore and Nanyang University are considered by a Joint Universities Admission Selection Committee established in 1974. The processing of applications to institutions of higher studies helps to maintain the standards of admission as well as fairness in the award of places which must be decided solely on the basis of merit, given students' preferences.

    The hon. Member seems to be worried about "wastage and unnecessary duplication or overlapping". I assume he is referring to courses offered at these institutions. There are, of course, courses common both to Nanyang and Singapore Universities and to Ngee Ann and the Polytechnic. For instance, both Universities teach Mathematics, Political Science, Statistics, Economics, Geography and History in the Arts and Social Science Departments. In Science subjects, Chemistry, Physics and Applied Physics are common to both Universities. I do not know

Column: 291

whether the Member believes that these subjects should be farmed out to one or the other of the Universities. I am not certain what merit there is in this idea, but serious problems of dislocation will arise for both staff and students. The two Universities have enough problems on their hands at the moment, and now is not the time to consider further innovations unless these have obvious merit.

    Much the same of what I said applies to courses common to the Singapore Polytechnic and the Ngee Ann Technical College.

    It is not feasible to have a single authority to take charge of Universities, Polytechnics and the Institute of Education, as well as the Industrial Training Board. The levels of instruction, the qualifications of students, the objectives of these institutions are so varied that combining them into one organisation is likely to create more problems than it solves.

ASEAN SOLIDARITY


    7. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs (a) whether ASEAN's political solidarity hitherto demonstrated and its pace of responding to sudden events such as the Australian air fare policy and the recent flare-ups among the Asian communist countries are satisfactory; (b) what is the best way to preserve the neutrality, peace and the territorial integrity of ASEAN; and (c) whether the recent events and developments in Indochina have created the need for a defence pact among ASEAN member countries to deter outside threats and to enhance the sense of stability within ASEAN.

     The Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Sir, ASEAN's response to the various developments in Indochina has demonstrated the solidarity of the group. The Vietnamese believed that ASEAN was a western imperialist creation and expected the group to fall into disarray with the withdrawal of United States military troops from Indochina. Instead of falling into disarray, ASEAN has become more united in its reaction to the turbulent political developments in the region.

Column: 292



    ASEAN solidarity was demonstrated by the unity of the ASEAN response to the Vietnamese invasion of Kampuchea. In fact, many non-aligned nations and members of the UN Security Council responded with the ASEAN line in their reaction to events in Kampuchea. The Sino-Vietnamese conflict has shown again the common ASEAN response and attitude to such events, Members would have noted from press reports that the ASEAN draft resolution, which was to be presented to the Security Council, commanded the most support and would have been presented and adopted by the Security Council were it not for USSR opposition.

    The Australian International Civil Aviation Policy is yet another example where ASEAN unity of purpose and solidarity were underestimated. Approaches were made, unsuccessfully, to ASEAN states individually with offers aimed at breaking rank. Statements were also made by some Australian officials that ASEAN solidarity was a fragile facade that would crack easily. Events so far have shown, while the coming meeting in Jakarta with the Australian Ministers will confirm, the grave error of such views.

    It is possible, indeed natural, that when five countries get together, there will be occasions when they will have disagreements, when each may have different ideas about particular regional or bilateral endeavours and questions. These occasional differences are often over less fundamental issues but they may be seen by others quite erroneously as lack of solidarity. The acid test of ASEAN solidarity is what ASEAN does when major issues affecting the vital interest of the region arise. The identity of purpose and swiftness of response to events that I have mentioned have amply demonstrated ASEAN solidarity. This has in fact become so clear that nations in other parts of the world have begun to look to ASEAN for a lead in matters affecting this region.

    As to the second part of the question, we have a region which has traditionally been an arena of great power rivalry and conflict. We

Column: 293

can expect that subversion, insurgency and limited proxy wars will continue as part of great power rivalry. It is therefore only prudent for ASEAN to recognise this reality. We in ASEAN will have to make a conscious effort to resist being drawn into these rivalries and conflicts. If we are not careful, we may find ourselves as proxies of the contending great powers. Non-involvement however does not mean that we turn a blind eye to regional and international issues which have serious political, economic ind security implications for ASEAN. We have to make known our position quite clearly. This we have done. The reaction of the ASEAN countries to each crisis in Southeast Asia has established clearly that ASEAN has a common and united position on major issues. Further we have shown that ASEAN's collective interest comes first and that we are not going to be drawn into taking sides in any great power rivalry. I can assure the hon. Member that this is the best way to preserve the neutrality, peace and territorial integrity of ASEAN.

    Coming to the third and final part of the question, when ASEAN was formed in 1967, it was clearly aimed at cooperation in economic, social and political fields. A military pact was never considered. In the 12 years since, there has never been any keen interest or effort in that direction.

    The threat of Communism cannot be contested by military pacts. It has to be fought through successful political, social and economic policies. Defence pacts are not geared to tackle the social and economic problems which provide fertile ground for Communist exploitation. Communist insurgencies and subversion thrive on poverty, class differences, uneven distribution of wealth, lack of economic opportunities and ignorance. The best method to combat the communist threat is through rapid social and economic development and by providing a better life for the people so that the people will find their society worth defending against the Communists.

Column: 294



    Economic cooperation within ASEAN can assist in solving these socio-economic problems. The conflicts among the Communist countries in Indochina provide ASEAN time to consolidate and to expand its efforts in economic development. We have to seize the opportunity presented to us now and use it to the fullest. More efforts have to be put into economic cooperation within ASEAN than has been the case in the past.

    The current conflicts in Indochina have introduced new forms of intervention in addition to subversion and externally supported insurgencies. The threat of a similar military intervention in ASEAN countries in the immediate future is small. As matters stand today, a military defence pact is not called for. But it is clear that the integrity of any partner in ASEAN is vital to the security of all partners. Any ASEAN response to events will therefore be guided by this principle.

NON-METRIC WEIGHING AND
MEASURING INSTRUMENTS
(Banning of)


    8. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Law and Science and Technology, in order that the metric system will be fully implemented, if he will consider introducing legislation to set a target date banning the use and sale of any non-metric weighing and measuring instruments in Singapore.

     Mr Lim Chee Onn (Bukit Merah) (for the Minister for Law and Science and Technology): Sir, the Government's policy is one of gradual conversion to the metric system. In other words, conversion will be implemented in phases after consultation and agreement with retailers, manufacturers, traders and importers. The metrication programmes for the public sector and the industrial sector have been completed, and the conversion of the retail trade sector is now under implementation.

    It is not intended at this stage to set a target date banning the use of non-metric

Column: 295

measuring and weighing instruments. Legislation will only be introduced in stages to ensure that there is no regression in areas which have been successfully convened into the metric system.

    9. Haji Sha'ari bin Tadin asked the Minister for Finance, in view of the many civil servants who opted for the "1973 Leave Scheme". whether he will consider allowing them the opportunity to reconsider their option.

CIVIL SERVICE REDUCED
VACATION AND MEDICAL LEAVE
(Review of monetary compensation)


    10. Haji Sha'ari bin Tadin asked the Minister for Finance whether he will consider reviewing the monetary compensation for the reduction in vacation and medical leave.

     The Senior Minister of State for Finance (Mr Goh Chok Tong) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, as Question No. 9 and Question No. 10 are related, could I have your permission to take the two Questions together?

     Mr Speaker: Yes.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, Members will recall that the late Member for Anson, Mr P. Govindaswamy, asked a similar question when the NWC wage increases were consolidated into basic salaries. I explained at that time that to revise leave allowances would be to leave the matter open for all time and so place an onerous burden on public funds.

    However, views of serving officers and choice of leave options of new recruits have led me to believe that our present leave scheme is not entirely satisfactory. Our experience since implementing the 1973 Leave Scheme shows that some revision will improve the Scheme. This is being considered and it will take some time to finalise.

Column: 296



     Mr Ho See Beng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to ask the Senior Minister of State for Finance this question. If a senior officer, whose compensation is, say, $150 for a period of 19 days, wishes to take unpaid leave for the same number of days, can he reimburse the Government with the same amount of compensation, that is, $150?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is no. The matter has been spelt out clearly in the option given to the officer serving at that time. Once he makes his option, it is irrevocable. But, as I explained just now, the matter is under review and it will take one to two months to finalise an improved leave scheme for the civil service.

     Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, I am asking a different question altogether. What I mean is whether the officer's pay will be cut by $150 if he takes 19 days' unpaid leave, since he has been compensated $150 for 19 days.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: I thought I have answered the Member's question in the first part. The answer is no.

JOB APPLICATIONS BY DRUG
OFFENDERS IN PUBLIC SERVICE
(Declaration of past convictions)


    11. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Finance whether he will consider asking Government departments, Government -owned companies and statutory boards to remove the requirement, if any, in job application forms for applicants to state whether they have been convicted of drug offence in the past, and if he will consider offering amnesty to civil servants and employees of Government-owned companies and statutory boards, who are drug addicts and wish to be cured of drug taking but dare not disclose their addiction for fear of dismissal.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, all applicants for appointments in the public service must declare whether they have been convicted by a court of law. This is so in every country. Conviction for a drug offence has, therefore,

Column: 297

to be declared. This is necessary as it has a bearing on the suita6ility of the candidate for public service and the type and nature of the job he will be given when he is appointed.

    Any officer in the Civil Service who volunteers for rehabilitative treatment because of drug addiction is helped and guided. He is granted sick leave followed by no-pay leave for the period of rehabilitation.

    The existing procedures of recruitment and treatment of drug offenders are necessary and I believe they meet the points raised by the hon. Member.

     Mr Ho See Beng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to ask the Senior Minister of State for Finance whether or not it is a waste of public funds and efforts to set up drug rehabilitation centres for drug addicts if the Government refuses to employ reformed drug addicts.

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not know whether or not the question is directed at drug addicts who were never employed in the civil service in the first place.

     Mr Ho See Beng: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I make myself clear? I said that if a reformed drug addict applied for a job in the Civil Service and if the Government was prejudiced against drug addicts, what then was the point of setting up drug rehabilitation centres? Would it not be a waste of public funds?

     Mr Goh Chok Tong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member is assuming that there is a prejudice on the part of the Government in employing reformed drug addicts who had never been in the service of the Government in the first place.

UPPER THOMSON CORRIDOR
(Measures to relieve traffic congestion)


    12. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for National Development what is the target date for the completion of Avenue 6 Ang Mo Kio, and, in the meantime, what immediate action is being or will be taken to

Column: 298

alleviate the deteriorating traffic congestion along Upper Thomson Road.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Mr Speaker, Sir, Avenue 6 Ang Mo Kio, from Sungei Kallang to Thomson Road, is scheduled for completion by the end of 1979. However, the stretch between Jalan Pemimpin and Thomson Road will be completed earlier, by August 1979, so that the traffic congestion at the junction of Upper Thomson Road, Braddell Road and Lornie Road can be eased as soon as the new road is ready.
